ratings.comment: Prof. Sifakis is knowledgeable on the subject matter and explains the contents clearly. He's also accessible outside of class. My greatest complaint is with his unclear "contract grading" policy, which grants the top 30% of satisfactory work full credits without a rubric. This makes it harder to gauge the amount of effort needed for a full score.

Sifakis clearly knows a ton about computer graphics and is passionate for the field, but teaches the content far too slowly in my opinion. That doesn't change that the content is great and the projects encourage you to experiment and be creative! Also, fantastic TAs and course staff that were willing to answer simple to very advanced questions.

Horrible competitive grading system that makes it very difficult to earn an A.  Compete with students who will write 500 - 1000 lines of code per weekly project, and in the end your grade will be based on subjective opinion.  Lectures are boring and weirdly paced, with tons of material overlap and no recordings.  Tests fine but barely affect grade.

I don't understand why he has a low rating. I took this class Fall 2022, and the class has changed a lot from when it first started (the class was originally in C++ but moved to Javascript based on student feedback). For both the midterm and final, we were allowed to have a note sheet and received practice exams. No required readings.

This guy has a very dull voice, lectures are not very inspiring. He seems pretty old-fashioned and doesn't want you emailing him. The grading is weird, and attendance to the dull lectures is kind of needed to understand what projects require. I think the topic would be interesting if presented in a different approach than his.

As average as professors come. Lectures are dry, but Efty gives very good study guides before exams. Your grade is heavily weighted by projects which are graded on a four-point scale. Getting a 3/4 on all projects and scoring decently on exams guarantees you a B. Many projects also already had examples that were almost 3 worthy. Overall, he's okay.

Great lecturer, but WORST grading policy I have ever seen. Each assignment is graded on a 4 point scale, only integer grades are possible, and the rubric for getting a 4 is to be "creative and interesting". This is extremely subjective and unfair, people spent 5 hours on assignments will have same grade as those who spent 15 minutes.

Don't take his class! The grading policy is extremely confusing: only about 1 / 3 of the assignments will get a 4 and the others, no matter how good they are, will get a 3. The lectures are very boring and makes you fall asleep easily.

Professor Sifakis is a fair and transparent grader, the grading rubric for this projects is released beforehand so you know what to do each project and how much time to spend. Unlike most professors that rely on cheap trick questions, he prepares a practice exam before each exam so you know what kind of questions to expect.

He is a very smart professor and it shows (did his PhD at Stanford). He is also humble and loves to answer questions. Homeworks are graded on a scale of 0-4 and he is very clear about what is needed. He prepares a sample test before exams. Very accommodating professor that I really appreciated especially during the rough time that is COVID-19.

Professor Sifakis is one of the best CS professors at UW-Madison. He is very clear on the grading criteria and he is probably the most understanding and caring professor Ive met. He really tries to accommodate his students as much as possible. He doesnt teach CS559 that often, but if he does Id absolutely recommend it.

Prof. Sifakis and just all the TA's this year were the most helpful teaching staff I've ever had. His lectures weren't great, and I did often skip, but he really got excited about what he was teaching and was incredibly active on Piazza, giving actually useful feedback. Overall really fun class!

Given the mediocre reviews on Prof Eftychios, I needed to say something. He's a really really great guy. I'm in my senior year and experienced a lot of CS professors that don't care about their students. He clearly does and he does a great job providing students with what they need to succeed. I have a lot of respect for him.

I loved this guy's class. We learned a lot of really, really cool stuff. The grading system was based on getting a score 1-5 on projects, 3 being sort of a B+, it met expectations, 4 being a polished, nice project, and 5 being an extraordinary project. I got mostly 4's when I thought I only deserved 3's. If you put in the effort, you will get A

You go to lecture to hear him discuss graphics concepts that are interesting, but then you have less than a week to program the graphics concept in a "cool, creative way" in JavaScript. 1) The grading structure and overall class structure is terrible 2) This class DOES NOT teach javascript, but uses it heavily. If you don't know it you're screwed

Prof. E.S. is definitely experienced with graphic programming but that doesn't make him a better teacher. His voice is hypnotizing and he has tough due days for the programs (less than a week!). But nevertheless, 559 is a have-to-take class, if you want to learn something cool. Also Prof. E.S. is not a tough grader, efforts paid off :).
Sifakis knows about the principles behind CG and clearly explains them. Projects are hard, but inspiring.

He is the worst professor I have had in my whole life, You will hear from him things about the importance of the hw on your final grade being average, beyond average, ... It is all a lie,  Your grade is determined based on how other people have performed in the class,  his non-written rule is that only 25-30% of the class may get an A

Sifakis' Computer Graphics class was well-taught. He went with the goal of not having the class become very involved in math but also introduce major concepts in graphics. Prepare for learning how to code in JavaScript and using matrix libraries. The amount of examples he provides helped a lot for me in coding assignments which are highly weighted.

I guess the difficulty of this course is caused by the course content instead of the professor. Computer graphic, with javascript can be quite intimidating, which makes it a 5 level course. Professor Sifakis actually is pretty nice. His lecture is more conceptual than practical, and really care about the student.

Honestly I am struggling through this course, but the professor is just so insightful. His lecture is a pure enjoyment. He explains everything in the most intuitive way and is definitely capable of doing so. For example, he teaches us the math we need in a pragmatic way which avoids boring proofs and definitions. Tolerant about late homework too.

Grading rubric for class is: "If you have everything 'OK', including hw and exam, you will get a B. If you did 'OK' on hw but get really good grades on the exam, then you will possibly get a higher letter grade. OK for the exam:  not clearly below the median OK for the programming assignment: get 3 for all of them" And that is all the info you get.

The organization of this class was beyond horrible. Constantly changing deadlines, assignment posts copied word for word from previous semesters without updating for our context, clarifications took days, we used a textbook that was half finished. On top of that, lecture was essentially useless. At least you get to make cool looking stuff

Honestly he is a horrible professor. Nothing we do in class correlates to the homework and I have yet to walk out of class not frustrated that he didn't waste my time. I'm sure I'll do fine in the class but I was very excited to learn HTML and JavaScript and I have learned 0 this semester.

I thought the material in this class was pretty hard. Very math-y as CS goes. He's obviously very smart, and he's not too difficult to understand. There is no textbook so you have to rely very heavily on his notes. Tests are weighted heavily. Wouldn't recommend it if you didn't enjoy calc 3.
